body: I agree this would be a nice improvement

Would anyone be against me picking up this issue? Any expectation upon its delivery? Reason why I ask is because this would be my first contribution and I don't want to block an important improvement to be delivered by someone more expert than me.

@antonmos I've investigated the code and it looks like Assertj makes a comparison between key sets and if they differ in size, it doesn't go further with the comparison because maps with different size are different already without the need of deep diving into entry differences. That's why you are missing the insights of differences between key sets.

Is your expectation to have a more insightful message providing the difference in key sets when they have different size? And do you want me to check for `symmetric` or `asymmetric` difference between the two key sets?

> Asymmetric difference – Finding those elements that are contained by set1 but not contained by set2
> Symmetric difference – Finding the elements in either of the sets but not in their intersection

Thank you for such prompt attention for this!

I think it should show you both symmetric and asymmetric differences.


I think closure's test functions do this really nicely.
Check out this write up https://jakemccrary.com/blog/2014/06/22/comparing-clojure-testing-libraries-output/

Specifically, it really helpful that it shows the diff in terms of missing and extra collection terma (e.g. for a map it shows the diff in terms of map.entries).

Pls let me know if the clojure example is not readable for you and I can elaborate.

I think it's clear what you are expecting. I will try to come up with an example of an assertion message but I'm afraid I will have to change some tests to adjust to the new output. I'll try to keep it as close-scoped as possible.

Any expectation when you would like me to finish this improvement?
Take the time you need, @simoneromani-90, no rush! And let us know if you need any help.

My 2cts: it's not that easy to produce the diff of what entries are missing and unexpected, remember you can't compare them with equals, you need to compare them recursively with the same config as the one of the initial assertion.

If that's too complicated, we could have a simpler approach where we display the actual and expected maps, that's a good compromise IMO.
@simoneromani-90 are you still willing to contribute this one ? (it's ok if you can't, no problem)

If you're okay with it, I'd be happy to work on the simpler approach of displaying the actual and expected maps.

@joel-costigliola @simoneromani-90
Great @kssumin, let's start with the simpler approach first
Hi there. @kssumin are you working on this? If not, can I take over?
